description: From Middle English clothen, from Old English clāþian (“to clothe”), from Proto-Germanic *klaiþōną (“to clothe”), from Proto-Indo-European *gley- (“to adhere to, stick”). Cognate with Dutch kleden, German kleiden, Swedish kläda, after apocope klä. See also cloth, clad.

verbs.description: clothe (third-person singular simple present clothes, present participle clothing, simple past and past participle clothed or (archaic) clad)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To adorn or cover with clothing; to dress; to supply clothes or clothing.
examples: to feed and clothe a family; to clothe oneself extravagantly

entries.meaning: (figurative) To cover or invest, as if with a garment.
examples: to clothe somebody with authority or power
